lifeEvents.title: Born in Honolulu, Hawaii
lifeEvents.description: Born at Kapiolani Medical Center for Women and Children to Stanley Ann Dunham (18) and Barack Obama Sr. (27), a Kenyan economist studying at University of Hawaii

lifeEvents.title: Parents divorced
lifeEvents.description: Parents divorced when Obama was 2 years old. Father returned to Kenya after studying at Harvard

lifeEvents.title: Mother remarried Indonesian student Lolo Soetoro
lifeEvents.description: Ann Dunham married Indonesian student Lolo Soetoro. Obama gained a half-sister Maya

lifeEvents.title: Lived in Indonesia
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Jakarta, Indonesia with mother and stepfather. Attended local Indonesian schools and received additional lessons via U.S. correspondence courses

lifeEvents.title: Returned to Hawaii to live with grandparents
lifeEvents.description: Returned to Hawaii to live with maternal grandparents Stanley and Madelyn Dunham. Attended Punahou School on scholarship

lifeEvents.title: Attended Occidental College
lifeEvents.description: First attended Occidental College in Los Angeles for two years

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Columbia University
lifeEvents.description: Transferred to Columbia University, earned Bachelor of Arts degree in political science. Lived ascetic life reading Shakespeare, Nietzsche, Toni Morrison

lifeEvents.title: Worked as community organizer in Chicago
lifeEvents.description: After working briefly for Business International Corp., took position as community organizer on Chicago's impoverished Far South Side

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Harvard Law School
lifeEvents.description: First African American to serve as president of the Harvard Law Review. Graduated magna cum laude

lifeEvents.title: Married Michelle Robinson
lifeEvents.description: Married Chicago lawyer Michelle Robinson, whom he met as a summer associate at Sidley Austin law firm in 1989

lifeEvents.title: Published 'Dreams from My Father'
lifeEvents.description: Published memoir about his search for identity and his father

lifeEvents.title: Elected to Illinois State Senate
lifeEvents.description: Elected to represent 13th district in Illinois Senate, served for 8 years

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Malia born
lifeEvents.description: First daughter Malia Ann Obama born

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Sasha born
lifeEvents.description: Second daughter Natasha (Sasha) Obama born

lifeEvents.title: Elected to U.S. Senate
lifeEvents.description: Elected by record majority to U.S. Senate from Illinois. Delivered acclaimed keynote at 2004 Democratic National Convention

lifeEvents.title: Published 'The Audacity of Hope'
lifeEvents.description: Published second book outlining his political vision

lifeEvents.title: Announced presidential candidacy
lifeEvents.description: Formally announced candidacy for President of the United States in Springfield, Illinois

lifeEvents.title: Won Democratic nomination
lifeEvents.description: Secured Democratic Party nomination after hard-fought primary against Hillary Clinton

lifeEvents.title: Elected President
lifeEvents.description: Became first African American elected President, defeating John McCain with 365 electoral votes

lifeEvents.title: Inaugurated as 44th President
lifeEvents.description: Inaugurated before estimated crowd of 1.8 million people. Began presidency during financial crisis and two wars

lifeEvents.title: Signed American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
lifeEvents.description: Signed $787 billion economic stimulus package to combat Great Recession

lifeEvents.title: Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: Became fourth U.S. President to receive Nobel Peace Prize

lifeEvents.title: Signed Affordable Care Act (Obamacare)
lifeEvents.description: Signed landmark healthcare reform legislation expanding coverage to millions of Americans

lifeEvents.title: Announced death of Osama bin Laden
lifeEvents.description: Announced successful U.S. military operation that killed al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden in Pakistan

lifeEvents.title: Re-elected for second term
lifeEvents.description: Won re-election defeating Mitt Romney with 332 electoral votes and 51.1% of popular vote

lifeEvents.title: Second inauguration
lifeEvents.description: Inaugurated for second term, sworn in privately on January 20, public ceremony January 21

lifeEvents.title: Announced Climate Action Plan
lifeEvents.description: Unveiled comprehensive plan to address climate change at Georgetown University

lifeEvents.title: Founded the Obama Foundation
lifeEvents.description: Established foundation to inspire and empower people to change their world

lifeEvents.title: Visited Cuba
lifeEvents.description: First sitting U.S. President to visit Cuba in 90 years, normalizing relations

lifeEvents.title: Left office
lifeEvents.description: Left office with high approval ratings, returned to private life in Washington D.C.

lifeEvents.title: Published memoir 'A Promised Land'
lifeEvents.description: Published first volume of presidential memoirs, became bestseller

lifeEvents.title: Born in Kosciusko, Mississippi
lifeEvents.description: Born to teenage mother Vernita Lee in rural Mississippi, raised in poverty

lifeEvents.title: Moved to Nashville with father
lifeEvents.description: Moved to live with father Vernon Winfrey in Nashville, excelled in school

lifeEvents.title: Started radio career
lifeEvents.description: Began working in radio while still in high school, youngest news anchor at Nashville's WLAC-TV

lifeEvents.title: Started Local TV Career
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Baltimore's WJZ-TV as co-anchor, then to Chicago's AM Chicago show

lifeEvents.title: Founded Harpo Productions
lifeEvents.description: Founded her own production company, becoming first African American woman to own a TV production company

lifeEvents.title: Debut of The Oprah Winfrey Show
lifeEvents.description: National syndication began, eventually becoming highest-rated daytime talk show in TV history

lifeEvents.title: Became National Talk Show Host
lifeEvents.description: Hosted The Oprah Winfrey Show for 25 years, revolutionizing daytime television

lifeEvents.title: Founded Oprah's Book Club
lifeEvents.description: Started book club that became most influential book club in the world

lifeEvents.title: Opened Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls
lifeEvents.description: Opened school for disadvantaged girls in South Africa, donated over $40 million

lifeEvents.title: Launched OWN Network
lifeEvents.description: Launched Oprah Winfrey Network (OWN) cable channel

lifeEvents.title: Received Presidential Medal of Freedom
lifeEvents.description: Awarded highest civilian honor by President Barack Obama

lifeEvents.title: Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award
lifeEvents.description: Received lifetime achievement award, gave powerful speech about Time's Up movement

lifeEvents.title: Born in San Francisco
lifeEvents.description: Born Steven Paul Jobs to Joanne Schieble and Abdulfattah Jandali, adopted by Paul and Clara Jobs

lifeEvents.title: Family moved to Los Altos
lifeEvents.description: Family moved to Los Altos, California in heart of Silicon Valley

lifeEvents.title: Met Steve Wozniak
lifeEvents.description: Met Steve Wozniak through friend Bill Fernandez at Homestead High School

lifeEvents.title: Reed College (dropped out)
lifeEvents.description: Attended Reed College for one semester, dropped out but continued auditing classes including calligraphy

lifeEvents.title: Trip to India
lifeEvents.description: Traveled to India seeking enlightenment, returned disillusioned but interested in Zen Buddhism

lifeEvents.title: Atari Employee
lifeEvents.description: Worked as technician at Atari video game company, known for his abrasive personality

lifeEvents.title: Founded Apple Computer
lifeEvents.description: Co-founded Apple with Steve Wozniak in the Jobs family garage, revolutionizing personal computing

lifeEvents.title: Apple II launched
lifeEvents.description: Launched Apple II, one of first successful mass-produced personal computers, made Apple fortune

lifeEvents.title: Apple went public
lifeEvents.description: Apple IPO created more millionaires than any company in history at that time

lifeEvents.title: Visit to Xerox PARC
lifeEvents.description: Visited Xerox PARC, saw graphical user interface and mouse technology that would inspire Macintosh

lifeEvents.title: Lisa computer launched
lifeEvents.description: Launched Lisa computer (named after daughter), featured GUI but was commercial failure due to high price

lifeEvents.title: Recruited John Sculley as CEO
lifeEvents.description: Convinced PepsiCo president John Sculley to join Apple with famous challenge: 'Do you want to sell sugar water?'

lifeEvents.title: Macintosh launched
lifeEvents.description: Launched Macintosh with iconic '1984' Super Bowl commercial, revolutionizing computer interfaces

lifeEvents.title: Forced out of Apple
lifeEvents.description: Lost power struggle with John Sculley, was marginalized and left Apple

lifeEvents.title: Founded NeXT Computer
lifeEvents.description: Founded NeXT Inc., designing powerful workstation computers, invested $12 million of own money

lifeEvents.title: Acquired Pixar
lifeEvents.description: Bought computer graphics division from Lucasfilm for $5 million, transformed it into animation studio

lifeEvents.title: NeXT computer launched
lifeEvents.description: Launched NeXT Computer, technically advanced but commercially unsuccessful due to high price

lifeEvents.title: Married Laurene Powell
lifeEvents.description: Married Stanford MBA student Laurene Powell at Yosemite National Park

lifeEvents.title: Son Reed born
lifeEvents.description: First child with Laurene Powell, son Reed Paul Jobs born

lifeEvents.title: Toy Story released
lifeEvents.description: Pixar's first feature film Toy Story released, first fully computer-animated feature film

lifeEvents.title: Pixar IPO
lifeEvents.description: Pixar went public one week after Toy Story release, made Jobs a billionaire

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Erin born
lifeEvents.description: Daughter Erin Siena Jobs born

lifeEvents.title: Apple acquired NeXT
lifeEvents.description: Apple bought NeXT for $400 million, brought Jobs back as advisor

lifeEvents.title: Son Eve born
lifeEvents.description: Daughter Eve Jobs born

lifeEvents.title: Returned to Apple as CEO
lifeEvents.description: Became interim CEO after Gil Amelio was ousted, later became permanent CEO

lifeEvents.title: Think Different campaign
lifeEvents.description: Launched 'Think Different' advertising campaign to restore Apple's brand

lifeEvents.title: iMac launched
lifeEvents.description: Launched translucent iMac, marked Apple's return to profitability and design leadership

lifeEvents.title: Introduction of iPod
lifeEvents.description: Launched iPod portable music player, revolutionized music industry and created new product category

lifeEvents.title: iTunes Store launched
lifeEvents.description: Opened iTunes Music Store, first legal digital music marketplace

lifeEvents.title: Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer
lifeEvents.description: Diagnosed with rare form of pancreatic cancer, initially delayed surgery for alternative treatments

lifeEvents.title: Pancreatic surgery
lifeEvents.description: Underwent Whipple procedure to remove pancreatic tumor at Stanford University Medical Center

lifeEvents.title: Stanford commencement speech
lifeEvents.description: Delivered famous 'Stay hungry, stay foolish' commencement address at Stanford University

lifeEvents.title: Disney acquired Pixar
lifeEvents.description: Disney bought Pixar for $7.4 billion, Jobs became Disney's largest individual shareholder

lifeEvents.title: Introduction of iPhone
lifeEvents.description: Unveiled iPhone at Macworld, revolutionizing smartphone industry with touchscreen interface

lifeEvents.title: iPhone launched
lifeEvents.description: iPhone went on sale, creating new smartphone market and transforming multiple industries

lifeEvents.title: Introduction of iPad
lifeEvents.description: Unveiled iPad tablet computer, created tablet computing market

lifeEvents.title: iPad launched
lifeEvents.description: iPad went on sale, sold 300,000 units on first day

lifeEvents.title: Medical Leave from Apple
lifeEvents.description: Took third medical leave as cancer returned, Tim Cook ran daily operations

lifeEvents.title: Resigned as CEO
lifeEvents.description: Resigned as CEO with letter: 'I have always said if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple's CEO, I would be the first to let you know. Unfortunately, that day has come.'

lifeEvents.title: Died
lifeEvents.description: Died at home in Palo Alto surrounded by family, complications from pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor

lifeEvents.title: Born in Pretoria, South Africa
lifeEvents.description: Born to Canadian mother Maye and South African father Errol Musk

lifeEvents.title: Created first video game
lifeEvents.description: At age 12, created and sold video game 'Blastar' to computer magazine for $500

lifeEvents.title: Parents divorced
lifeEvents.description: Parents divorced when Elon was 10 years old

lifeEvents.title: Moved to Canada
lifeEvents.description: At age 17, moved to Canada to avoid South African military service and gained Canadian citizenship through mother

lifeEvents.title: Attended Queen's University
lifeEvents.description: Studied at Queen's University in Ontario, Canada for two years

lifeEvents.title: Transferred to University of Pennsylvania
lifeEvents.description: Earned bachelor's degrees in economics and physics from University of Pennsylvania

lifeEvents.title: Stanford PhD program (dropped out)
lifeEvents.description: Enrolled in PhD program in energy physics at Stanford but dropped out after 2 days to start business

lifeEvents.title: Co‑founded Zip2
lifeEvents.description: Co-founded Zip2 with brother Kimbal, online city guide providing content for newspapers like New York Times

lifeEvents.title: Zip2 sold to Compaq
lifeEvents.description: Compaq acquired Zip2 for $307 million cash and $34 million stock options, Musk received $22 million

lifeEvents.title: Founded X.com/PayPal
lifeEvents.description: Founded X.com online financial services company, which merged with Confinity to become PayPal

lifeEvents.title: Married Justine Wilson
lifeEvents.description: Married Canadian author Justine Wilson, whom he met at Queen's University

lifeEvents.title: First son Nevada died
lifeEvents.description: First son Nevada Alexander died at 10 weeks old from sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)

lifeEvents.title: Became U.S. citizen
lifeEvents.description: Became American citizen while retaining Canadian and South African citizenships

lifeEvents.title: PayPal sold to eBay
lifeEvents.description: eBay acquired PayPal for $1.5 billion, Musk received $165 million as largest shareholder (11.7%)

lifeEvents.title: Founded SpaceX
lifeEvents.description: Founded Space Exploration Technologies (SpaceX) with goal of reducing space transportation costs and Mars colonization

lifeEvents.title: Twins Griffin and Xavier born
lifeEvents.description: Twin sons Griffin and Xavier born via IVF to Justine Wilson

lifeEvents.title: Joined Tesla Motors
lifeEvents.description: Led Series A funding round with $6.35 million investment, became chairman and later CEO of electric car company

lifeEvents.title: Triplets born
lifeEvents.description: Triplet sons Kai, Saxon, and Damian born via IVF to Justine Wilson

lifeEvents.title: First SpaceX rocket failure
lifeEvents.description: Falcon 1's first launch failed 25 seconds after liftoff

lifeEvents.title: Co-founded SolarCity
lifeEvents.description: Co-founded solar energy services company with cousins Lyndon and Peter Rive

lifeEvents.title: Tesla Roadster unveiled
lifeEvents.description: Tesla's first car, the Roadster sports car, capable of 0-60 mph in 3.7 seconds and 250-mile range

lifeEvents.title: SpaceX Falcon 1 reaches orbit
lifeEvents.description: Fourth Falcon 1 flight successful, first privately-developed liquid-fueled rocket to reach orbit

lifeEvents.title: Divorced Justine Wilson
lifeEvents.description: Divorced first wife Justine Wilson after 8 years of marriage

lifeEvents.title: Nearly went bankrupt
lifeEvents.description: Both Tesla and SpaceX nearly failed during financial crisis, Musk invested last personal funds

lifeEvents.title: Married Talulah Riley
lifeEvents.description: Married British actress Talulah Riley (divorced 2012, remarried 2013, divorced again 2016)

lifeEvents.title: Tesla IPO
lifeEvents.description: Tesla went public, first American car company IPO since Ford in 1956

lifeEvents.title: SpaceX Dragon reaches ISS
lifeEvents.description: First commercial spacecraft to dock with International Space Station

lifeEvents.title: Hyperloop concept unveiled
lifeEvents.description: Proposed high-speed transportation system using pods in low-pressure tubes

lifeEvents.title: First Falcon 9 landing attempt
lifeEvents.description: First attempt to land Falcon 9 first stage on autonomous spaceport drone ship

lifeEvents.title: First successful Falcon 9 landing
lifeEvents.description: First successful landing of orbital-class rocket first stage, revolutionizing spaceflight

lifeEvents.title: Founded Neuralink
lifeEvents.description: Founded neurotechnology company developing brain-computer interfaces

lifeEvents.title: Founded The Boring Company
lifeEvents.description: Founded tunnel construction company to reduce traffic congestion

lifeEvents.title: Son X Æ A-XII born
lifeEvents.description: Son born to musician Grimes (Claire Boucher), name later changed to X Æ A-Xii

lifeEvents.title: Tesla becomes most valuable automaker
lifeEvents.description: Tesla's market capitalization exceeded all other automakers

lifeEvents.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon first crewed flight
lifeEvents.description: First crewed spaceflight by private company, transported NASA astronauts to ISS

lifeEvents.title: Became world's richest person
lifeEvents.description: Net worth surpassed Jeff Bezos to become world's wealthiest person

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Exa Dark Sideræl born
lifeEvents.description: Second child with Grimes, nicknamed 'Y'

lifeEvents.title: Acquired Twitter
lifeEvents.description: Acquired Twitter for $44 billion, later rebranded as 'X'

lifeEvents.title: Twins born via surrogate
lifeEvents.description: Twins born with Shivon Zilis, Neuralink executive

lifeEvents.title: Starship first orbital test
lifeEvents.description: First integrated test flight of Starship rocket system, exploded after 4 minutes

lifeEvents.title: Third child with Grimes
lifeEvents.description: Third child Techno Mechanicus born to Grimes via surrogate

lifeEvents.title: Appointed to DOGE
lifeEvents.description: Led Department of Government Efficiency under President Trump's second administration

lifeEvents.title: Departed DOGE role
lifeEvents.description: Stepped down from government efficiency role after 4 months

lifeEvents.title: Born in Chicago, Illinois
lifeEvents.description: Born Michelle LaVaughn Robinson on South Side of Chicago to Fraser and Marian Robinson

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Princeton University
lifeEvents.description: Graduated cum laude with bachelor's degree in sociology, wrote senior thesis on African-American Princeton alumni

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Harvard Law School
lifeEvents.description: Earned Juris Doctor degree, worked as research assistant to Harvard Law professor

lifeEvents.title: Joined Sidley Austin law firm
lifeEvents.description: Worked as associate specializing in marketing and intellectual property law

lifeEvents.title: Met Barack Obama
lifeEvents.description: Met Barack Obama when he was summer associate at Sidley Austin, she was his mentor

lifeEvents.title: Married Barack Obama
lifeEvents.description: Married Barack Obama at Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago

lifeEvents.title: Worked at Chicago city government
lifeEvents.description: Assistant to Mayor Richard M. Daley and then Assistant Commissioner of Planning and Development

lifeEvents.title: Executive Director of Public Allies Chicago
lifeEvents.description: Founded Chicago chapter of Public Allies, nonprofit preparing young people for public service careers

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Malia born
lifeEvents.description: First daughter Malia Ann Obama born on Independence Day

lifeEvents.title: Associate Dean at University of Chicago
lifeEvents.description: Worked in student services at University of Chicago, later Associate Dean of Student Services

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Sasha born
lifeEvents.description: Second daughter Natasha (Sasha) Obama born

lifeEvents.title: Executive Director for Community Affairs, University of Chicago Medical Center
lifeEvents.description: Worked to build relationships between medical center and community

lifeEvents.title: Vice President for Community and External Affairs
lifeEvents.description: Promoted at University of Chicago Medical Center with significant salary increase

lifeEvents.title: Served as First Lady of the United States
lifeEvents.description: First African American First Lady, focused on issues like healthy eating, education, military families

lifeEvents.title: Launched Let's Move! campaign
lifeEvents.description: Comprehensive initiative to address childhood obesity epidemic through healthy eating and physical activity

lifeEvents.title: Launched Let Girls Learn initiative
lifeEvents.description: Global initiative to help adolescent girls attend and complete school

lifeEvents.title: Democratic National Convention speech
lifeEvents.description: Delivered powerful speech including famous line 'When they go low, we go high'

lifeEvents.title: Final speech as First Lady
lifeEvents.description: Emotional farewell speech at White House, thanked young people for inspiring her

lifeEvents.title: Authored 'Becoming'
lifeEvents.description: Published memoir that became one of best-selling books of 2018, sold over 10 million copies

lifeEvents.title: Launched 'Becoming' book tour
lifeEvents.description: Massive book tour across 34 cities, selling out arenas and becoming cultural phenomenon

lifeEvents.title: Founded Higher Ground Productions
lifeEvents.description: Production company with Barack Obama for Netflix content creation

lifeEvents.title: Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album
lifeEvents.description: Won Grammy for audiobook version of 'Becoming'

lifeEvents.title: Launched 'The Michelle Obama Podcast'
lifeEvents.description: Exclusive Spotify podcast featuring conversations on relationships and life

lifeEvents.title: Born in Seattle, Washington
lifeEvents.description: Born William Henry Gates III to attorney William H. Gates Sr. and Mary Maxwell Gates

lifeEvents.title: First encounter with computers
lifeEvents.description: At age 13, first used computer at Lakeside School, expensive private preparatory school

lifeEvents.title: Met Paul Allen
lifeEvents.description: Formed friendship with Paul Allen at Lakeside School, bonded over computers

lifeEvents.title: First business venture
lifeEvents.description: Created Traf-O-Data with Paul Allen, analyzing traffic data, earned $20,000

lifeEvents.title: Enrolled at Harvard University
lifeEvents.description: Studied mathematics and computer science, scored 1590 out of 1600 on SATs

lifeEvents.title: Co‑founded Microsoft
lifeEvents.description: Founded Microsoft with Paul Allen in Albuquerque, New Mexico, initially called 'Micro-Soft'

lifeEvents.title: Dropped out of Harvard
lifeEvents.description: Left Harvard during sophomore year to focus on Microsoft full-time

lifeEvents.title: IBM PC partnership
lifeEvents.description: Secured contract to provide operating system (MS-DOS) for IBM Personal Computer

lifeEvents.title: Microsoft IPO
lifeEvents.description: Microsoft went public at $21 per share, creating several millionaires including Gates

lifeEvents.title: Became world's youngest billionaire
lifeEvents.description: At age 31, became youngest person ever to appear on Forbes list of richest people

lifeEvents.title: Achieved Peak Wealth
lifeEvents.description: Dominated as world's richest person for most of 1990s due to Microsoft's success

lifeEvents.title: Windows 95 launched
lifeEvents.description: Revolutionary operating system launch with massive marketing campaign, sold 1 million copies in 4 days

lifeEvents.title: Married Melinda French
lifeEvents.description: Married Melinda French, former Microsoft employee, in Hawaii

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Jennifer born
lifeEvents.description: First child Jennifer Katharine Gates born

lifeEvents.title: Published 'The Road Ahead'
lifeEvents.description: Book about future of technology and information highway, became bestseller

lifeEvents.title: Son Rory born
lifeEvents.description: Son Rory John Gates born

lifeEvents.title: Founded the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
lifeEvents.description: Merged William H. Gates Foundation and Gates Learning Foundation, became world's largest private charitable foundation

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Phoebe born
lifeEvents.description: Youngest child Phoebe Adele Gates born

lifeEvents.title: Transitioned from Microsoft
lifeEvents.description: Stepped down from day-to-day operations at Microsoft to focus on foundation work

lifeEvents.title: Launched Giving Pledge
lifeEvents.description: With Warren Buffett, created commitment for billionaires to give majority of wealth to philanthropy

lifeEvents.title: Left Microsoft board
lifeEvents.description: Resigned from Microsoft board to focus on philanthropy and global health initiatives

lifeEvents.title: COVID-19 response leadership
lifeEvents.description: Foundation committed billions to COVID-19 response, vaccine development and distribution globally

lifeEvents.title: Divorced Melinda French
lifeEvents.description: Divorced after 27 years of marriage, continued joint leadership of foundation

lifeEvents.title: Published 'How to Prevent the Next Pandemic'
lifeEvents.description: Book outlining lessons from COVID-19 and strategies for preventing future pandemics

lifeEvents.title: Born in Mingora, Pakistan
lifeEvents.description: Born in Swat District, Pakistan, to educator Ziauddin Yousafzai and Tor Pekai Yousafzai

lifeEvents.title: Father opened school for girls
lifeEvents.description: Father Ziauddin opened Khushal Girls High School and College, inspiring Malala's activism

lifeEvents.title: Taliban took control of Swat Valley
lifeEvents.description: Taliban imposed strict Islamic law, banned girls from attending school

lifeEvents.title: Advocated for Girls' Education
lifeEvents.description: Began speaking publicly about girls' education rights despite Taliban threats

lifeEvents.title: BBC blog under pseudonym
lifeEvents.description: Wrote anonymous blog for BBC Urdu under name 'Gul Makai' about life under Taliban rule

lifeEvents.title: Featured in documentary
lifeEvents.description: Featured in New York Times documentary 'Class Dismissed' about Taliban's impact on education

lifeEvents.title: First Peace Prize for Youth
lifeEvents.description: Awarded Pakistan's first National Youth Peace Prize for advocacy work

lifeEvents.title: Nominated for International Children's Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: First Pakistani girl nominated for prestigious international award

lifeEvents.title: Survived a Taliban Attack
lifeEvents.description: Shot in head by Taliban gunman while returning from school, critically injured

lifeEvents.title: Emergency treatment in Birmingham
lifeEvents.description: Airlifted to Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham for life-saving treatment and recovery

lifeEvents.title: Family relocated to UK
lifeEvents.description: Family moved to Birmingham permanently for safety and Malala's continued treatment

lifeEvents.title: Published 'I Am Malala'
lifeEvents.description: Memoir co-written with Christina Lamb became international bestseller

lifeEvents.title: Launched Malala Fund
lifeEvents.description: Founded organization to advocate for girls' education globally

lifeEvents.title: Address to United Nations
lifeEvents.description: Delivered speech to UN on 16th birthday, declared it 'Malala Day'

lifeEvents.title: Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: At age 17, became youngest person ever to receive Nobel Peace Prize, shared with Kailash Satyarthi

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Oxford University
lifeEvents.description: Earned degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics from Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford

lifeEvents.title: Married Asser Malik
lifeEvents.description: Married Pakistan Cricket Board official in Birmingham ceremony

lifeEvents.title: Produced first film
lifeEvents.description: Executive produced documentary 'Stranger at the Gate' about Islamophobia

lifeEvents.title: Born in Mvezo, South Africa
lifeEvents.description: Born Rolihlahla Mandela in village of Mvezo, Transkei, South Africa, to Thembu royal family

lifeEvents.title: Father died
lifeEvents.description: Father Henry Gadla Mandela died when Nelson was 9, moved to live with regent Jongintaba

lifeEvents.title: Attended University of Fort Hare
lifeEvents.description: Studied at elite University of Fort Hare, suspended for participating in student protest

lifeEvents.title: Fled arranged marriage
lifeEvents.description: Escaped to Johannesburg to avoid arranged marriage chosen by regent

lifeEvents.title: Worked as mine security guard
lifeEvents.description: Worked various jobs in Johannesburg, first exposure to racial inequalities in city

lifeEvents.title: Earned law degree
lifeEvents.description: Completed Bachelor of Arts degree through correspondence with University of South Africa

lifeEvents.title: Joined African National Congress
lifeEvents.description: Joined ANC and co-founded ANC Youth League with Oliver Tambo and Walter Sisulu

lifeEvents.title: Opened first black law firm
lifeEvents.description: Opened first black law partnership in South Africa with Oliver Tambo

lifeEvents.title: Led Defiance Campaign
lifeEvents.description: Organized nationwide civil disobedience campaign against unjust apartheid laws

lifeEvents.title: First marriage to Evelyn Mase
lifeEvents.description: Married nurse Evelyn Mase, had four children including Thembi and Makgatho

lifeEvents.title: Treason Trial began
lifeEvents.description: Arrested with 155 others for treason, trial lasted over 4 years, ultimately acquitted

lifeEvents.title: Married Winnie Madikizela
lifeEvents.description: Married activist Winnie Madikizela, had two daughters Zenani and Zindziswa

lifeEvents.title: Sharpeville Massacre response
lifeEvents.description: After police killed 69 peaceful protesters, convinced ANC to abandon non-violent tactics

lifeEvents.title: Founded Umkhonto we Sizwe
lifeEvents.description: Co-founded armed wing of ANC, planned sabotage campaign against government infrastructure

lifeEvents.title: Left South Africa secretly
lifeEvents.description: Traveled internationally for military training and to gain support for anti-apartheid struggle

lifeEvents.title: Arrested and imprisoned
lifeEvents.description: Arrested near Howick, KwaZulu-Natal, began 27 years of imprisonment

lifeEvents.title: Rivonia Trial
lifeEvents.description: Tried for sabotage, delivered famous 'I am prepared to die' speech, sentenced to life imprisonment

lifeEvents.title: Robben Island imprisonment
lifeEvents.description: Spent 18 years on Robben Island in harsh conditions, hard labor in lime quarry

lifeEvents.title: Transferred to Pollsmoor Prison
lifeEvents.description: Moved to mainland prison with better conditions, began secret negotiations with government

lifeEvents.title: Secret meetings with government
lifeEvents.description: Began clandestine talks with apartheid government about transition to democracy

lifeEvents.title: Transferred to Victor Verster Prison
lifeEvents.description: Final prison, lived in house on prison grounds, continued negotiations

lifeEvents.title: Released from Prison
lifeEvents.description: Released after 27 years, walked free with Winnie, watched by 1 billion people globally

lifeEvents.title: Began formal negotiations
lifeEvents.description: Led ANC in negotiations with F.W. de Klerk's government for democratic transition

lifeEvents.title: Separated from Winnie
lifeEvents.description: Announced separation from wife Winnie amid controversies surrounding her activities

lifeEvents.title: Received the Nobel Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: Shared Nobel Peace Prize with F.W. de Klerk for peaceful transition from apartheid

lifeEvents.title: Voted in first democratic election
lifeEvents.description: Cast ballot in South Africa's first fully democratic elections at age 75

lifeEvents.title: Elected President of South Africa
lifeEvents.description: Became South Africa's first black president, focused on reconciliation and nation-building

lifeEvents.title: Truth and Reconciliation Commission
lifeEvents.description: Established commission led by Desmond Tutu to investigate apartheid-era human rights violations

lifeEvents.title: Rugby World Cup victory
lifeEvents.description: Presented trophy to Springboks captain Francois Pienaar, powerful symbol of reconciliation

lifeEvents.title: Divorced Winnie
lifeEvents.description: Finalized divorce from Winnie Mandela after 38-year marriage

lifeEvents.title: Married Graça Machel
lifeEvents.description: Married former Mozambique First Lady on his 80th birthday

lifeEvents.title: Founded the Nelson Mandela Foundation
lifeEvents.description: Established foundation to promote his vision of freedom and equality on final day as president

lifeEvents.title: Retired from public life
lifeEvents.description: Announced retirement from public life at age 85 to spend time with family

lifeEvents.title: Son Makgatho died of AIDS
lifeEvents.description: Publicly announced son's death from AIDS to reduce stigma around the disease

lifeEvents.title: 90th birthday celebration
lifeEvents.description: Global celebration of 90th birthday, Nelson Mandela International Day established

lifeEvents.title: Last public appearance
lifeEvents.description: Final public appearance at FIFA World Cup closing ceremony in South Africa

lifeEvents.title: Hospitalized for lung infection
lifeEvents.description: Spent nearly three months in hospital with recurring lung infection

lifeEvents.title: Died peacefully at home
lifeEvents.description: Died at age 95 at home in Houghton surrounded by family, South Africa mourned for 10 days

lifeEvents.title: Born in Ulm, Germany
lifeEvents.description: Born to Hermann Einstein (featherbed salesman) and Pauline Koch in Kingdom of Württemberg

lifeEvents.title: Family moved to Munich
lifeEvents.description: Family moved to Munich where father and uncle founded electrical equipment factory

lifeEvents.title: First wonder - compass encounter
lifeEvents.description: Age 5, mystified by compass needle being deflected by invisible forces, sparked lifelong fascination

lifeEvents.title: Early Education in Munich
lifeEvents.description: Attended St. Peter's Catholic elementary school, then Luitpold Gymnasium

lifeEvents.title: Sister Maja born
lifeEvents.description: Sister Maria (Maja) born, became lifelong close companion

lifeEvents.title: Second wonder - geometry book
lifeEvents.description: Age 12, discovered geometry book, called it his 'sacred little geometry book'

lifeEvents.title: Became deeply religious
lifeEvents.description: Composed religious songs and chanted on way to school, later abandoned religion for science

lifeEvents.title: Family financial troubles
lifeEvents.description: Father's business failed, family moved to Italy leaving Einstein in Munich to finish school

lifeEvents.title: Dropped out of gymnasium
lifeEvents.description: Left school without diploma, joined family in Milan, rebelled against authoritarian education

lifeEvents.title: Education in Switzerland
lifeEvents.description: Failed entrance exam for ETH Zurich, attended Aargau school, graduated in 1896

lifeEvents.title: Renounced German citizenship
lifeEvents.description: Gave up German citizenship to avoid military service, remained stateless until 1901

lifeEvents.title: Entered Swiss Federal Polytechnic
lifeEvents.description: Studied physics and mathematics in Zurich, described as happiest years of his life

lifeEvents.title: Met future wife Mileva Marić
lifeEvents.description: Met Serbian physics student Mileva Marić, one of few women in physics program

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from ETH
lifeEvents.description: Graduated with teaching diploma, had difficulty finding academic position

lifeEvents.title: Gained Swiss citizenship
lifeEvents.description: Became Swiss citizen after 5 years of statelessness

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Lieserl born
lifeEvents.description: Secret daughter born to Mileva before marriage, fate unknown - likely died or adopted

lifeEvents.title: Patent Clerk in Bern
lifeEvents.description: Worked at Swiss Patent Office evaluating electromagnetic devices, had time for theoretical physics

lifeEvents.title: Married Mileva Marić
lifeEvents.description: Married in small ceremony in Bern, despite family opposition

lifeEvents.title: Olympia Academy formed
lifeEvents.description: Informal discussion group with Maurice Solovine and Conrad Habicht to discuss philosophy and physics

lifeEvents.title: Son Hans Albert born
lifeEvents.description: First legitimate son born, became hydraulic engineer

lifeEvents.title: Received doctorate
lifeEvents.description: Earned PhD from University of Zurich with dissertation on molecular dimensions

lifeEvents.title: Annus Mirabilis - Miracle Year
lifeEvents.description: Published four groundbreaking papers: photoelectric effect, Brownian motion, special relativity, mass-energy equivalence

lifeEvents.title: Special Relativity Published
lifeEvents.description: Published 'On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies' introducing special theory of relativity

lifeEvents.title: E=mc² equation published
lifeEvents.description: Published mass-energy equivalence paper, most famous equation in physics

lifeEvents.title: Became Privatdozent
lifeEvents.description: Appointed lecturer at University of Bern while continuing patent office work

lifeEvents.title: University of Zurich
lifeEvents.description: First full professorship at University of Zurich, left patent office

lifeEvents.title: Son Eduard born
lifeEvents.description: Second son born, later developed schizophrenia

lifeEvents.title: Professor in Prague
lifeEvents.description: Full professor at German University in Prague, worked on general relativity

lifeEvents.title: Returned to ETH Zurich
lifeEvents.description: Professor at his alma mater, continued developing general relativity theory

lifeEvents.title: University of Berlin
lifeEvents.description: Prestigious position at Prussian Academy of Sciences, no teaching duties

lifeEvents.title: World War I began
lifeEvents.description: Became pacifist, opposed to war while living in militaristic Germany

lifeEvents.title: Marriage dissolved
lifeEvents.description: Separated from Mileva, she returned to Zurich with children

lifeEvents.title: General Relativity Published
lifeEvents.description: Presented field equations of general relativity to Prussian Academy

lifeEvents.title: Divorced Mileva
lifeEvents.description: Finalized divorce, promised Nobel Prize money to Mileva

lifeEvents.title: Married cousin Elsa
lifeEvents.description: Married cousin Elsa Löwenthal in Berlin

lifeEvents.title: Solar eclipse confirms relativity
lifeEvents.description: Eddington's eclipse expedition confirmed light bending prediction, Einstein became world famous

lifeEvents.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
lifeEvents.description: Awarded Nobel Prize for photoelectric effect (not relativity), delayed until 1922

lifeEvents.title: First visit to United States
lifeEvents.description: Lecture tour to raise funds for Hebrew University in Palestine

lifeEvents.title: Quantum mechanics debates with Bohr
lifeEvents.description: Famous debates about quantum mechanics interpretation, 'God does not play dice' quote

lifeEvents.title: Unified field theory work
lifeEvents.description: Spent later years trying unsuccessfully to unify electromagnetic and gravitational forces

lifeEvents.title: Nazi rise to power
lifeEvents.description: Hitler became Chancellor, Einstein's books burned, property confiscated

lifeEvents.title: Left Germany permanently
lifeEvents.description: Resigned from Prussian Academy, never returned to Germany

lifeEvents.title: Princeton Institute for Advanced Study
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Princeton, New Jersey, worked there until death

lifeEvents.title: Wife Elsa died
lifeEvents.description: Second wife Elsa died of heart and liver problems

lifeEvents.title: Letter to Roosevelt about atomic bomb
lifeEvents.description: Warned President Roosevelt that Germany might develop atomic weapons, urged U.S. research

lifeEvents.title: Became U.S. citizen
lifeEvents.description: Became American citizen while retaining Swiss citizenship

lifeEvents.title: Atomic bombs dropped
lifeEvents.description: Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombed, Einstein called it 'one great mistake' of his life

lifeEvents.title: Became peace activist
lifeEvents.description: Advocated for nuclear disarmament and world government after atomic bombs

lifeEvents.title: Offered Israeli presidency
lifeEvents.description: Declined offer to become second President of Israel after Chaim Weizmann's death

lifeEvents.title: Refused surgery for aneurysm
lifeEvents.description: Abdominal aortic aneurysm burst, refused surgery saying 'I want to go when I want'

lifeEvents.title: Died in Princeton
lifeEvents.description: Died at age 76 at Princeton Hospital, brain removed for study without family permission

lifeEvents.title: Born in Yate, England
lifeEvents.description: Born Joanne Rowling in Yate, Gloucestershire, to Peter and Anne Rowling

lifeEvents.title: Family moved to Winterbourne
lifeEvents.description: Family moved to nearby Winterbourne where she attended primary school

lifeEvents.title: Family moved to Wales
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Tutshill near Chepstow, Wales, when she was 9 years old

lifeEvents.title: Attended University of Exeter
lifeEvents.description: Studied French and Classics, graduated with 2:2 honors degree

lifeEvents.title: Worked for Amnesty International
lifeEvents.description: Worked as researcher and bilingual secretary for Amnesty International in London

lifeEvents.title: Mother died of multiple sclerosis
lifeEvents.description: Mother Anne died at age 45, profoundly influenced Rowling's writing about death and loss

lifeEvents.title: Moved to Portugal
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Porto, Portugal to teach English as foreign language

lifeEvents.title: Harry Potter idea conceived
lifeEvents.description: Idea for Harry Potter came during delayed train journey from Manchester to London

lifeEvents.title: Married Jorge Arantes
lifeEvents.description: Married Portuguese television journalist Jorge Arantes

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Jessica born
lifeEvents.description: First child Jessica Isabel Rowling Arantes born

lifeEvents.title: Divorced and returned to UK
lifeEvents.description: Marriage ended in domestic violence, returned to UK as single mother

lifeEvents.title: Moved to Edinburgh
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Edinburgh to be near sister, struggled as single mother on benefits

lifeEvents.title: Wrote first Harry Potter book
lifeEvents.description: Wrote much of first book in Edinburgh cafés while daughter slept, lived in poverty

lifeEvents.title: Completed teacher training
lifeEvents.description: Completed Postgraduate Certificate in Education at Moray House

lifeEvents.title: Finished Harry Potter manuscript
lifeEvents.description: Completed 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone' manuscript

lifeEvents.title: Sought literary agent
lifeEvents.description: Manuscript rejected by 12 publishers before Bloomsbury accepted it

lifeEvents.title: Published 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'
lifeEvents.description: First Harry Potter book published with initial print run of only 1,000 copies

lifeEvents.title: Won Nestlé Smarties Book Prize
lifeEvents.description: First book won prestigious children's book award, gaining recognition

lifeEvents.title: Published Chamber of Secrets
lifeEvents.description: Second Harry Potter book published to greater acclaim

lifeEvents.title: U.S. publication rights sold
lifeEvents.description: Scholastic bought U.S. rights for $105,000, highest amount ever for children's book by unknown author

lifeEvents.title: Published Prisoner of Azkaban
lifeEvents.description: Third book published, won numerous awards including Whitbread Children's Book Award

lifeEvents.title: Founded Volant Charitable Trust
lifeEvents.description: Established charity to combat poverty and social inequality, particularly affecting women and children

lifeEvents.title: Published Goblet of Fire
lifeEvents.description: Fourth book published, first to simultaneously top children's and adult bestseller lists

lifeEvents.title: Married Neil Murray
lifeEvents.description: Married Scottish doctor Neil Murray in private ceremony

lifeEvents.title: First Harry Potter film released
lifeEvents.description: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone film premiered, becoming massive success

lifeEvents.title: Son David born
lifeEvents.description: Son David Gordon Rowling Murray born

lifeEvents.title: Published Order of the Phoenix
lifeEvents.description: Fifth book published, longest in series at 870 pages

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Mackenzie born
lifeEvents.description: Daughter Mackenzie Jean Rowling Murray born

lifeEvents.title: Published Half-Blood Prince
lifeEvents.description: Sixth book published, sold 6.9 million copies in first 24 hours

lifeEvents.title: Published Deathly Hallows
lifeEvents.description: Final Harry Potter book published, concluded the series with record-breaking sales

lifeEvents.title: Received honorary degree from Harvard
lifeEvents.description: Delivered commencement address 'The Fringe Benefits of Failure' at Harvard University

lifeEvents.title: Published The Tales of Beedle the Bard
lifeEvents.description: Published companion book to Harry Potter series for charity

lifeEvents.title: Opened charity in Scotland
lifeEvents.description: Opened Lumos (formerly Children's High Level Group) to help institutionalized children

lifeEvents.title: Published The Casual Vacancy
lifeEvents.description: First adult novel published, dealt with social and political themes

lifeEvents.title: Published The Cuckoo's Calling under pseudonym
lifeEvents.description: Crime novel published under pseudonym Robert Galbraith, identity revealed later

lifeEvents.title: Continued Cormoran Strike series
lifeEvents.description: Published multiple detective novels under Robert Galbraith pseudonym

lifeEvents.title: Fantastic Beasts film series began
lifeEvents.description: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them film released, Rowling's screenwriting debut

lifeEvents.title: Born in Los Angeles, California
lifeEvents.description: Born to Irmelin Indenbirken and George DiCaprio in Hollywood, California

lifeEvents.title: Parents separated
lifeEvents.description: Parents divorced when Leonardo was one year old, raised primarily by mother

lifeEvents.title: Started acting in commercials
lifeEvents.description: Began acting career appearing in TV commercials and educational films

lifeEvents.title: Launched Acting Career
lifeEvents.description: Started with TV shows including 'Growing Pains' and various guest appearances

lifeEvents.title: Film debut in Critters 3
lifeEvents.description: Made film debut in low-budget horror sequel Critters 3

lifeEvents.title: Breakthrough role in This Boy's Life
lifeEvents.description: Starred opposite Robert De Niro, gained critical acclaim for dramatic performance

lifeEvents.title: What's Eating Gilbert Grape
lifeEvents.description: Played mentally disabled Arnie Grape, earned first Academy Award nomination at age 19

lifeEvents.title: Romeo + Juliet modern adaptation
lifeEvents.description: Starred in Baz Luhrmann's modern adaptation, became teen heartthrob

lifeEvents.title: Starred in 'Titanic'
lifeEvents.description: Played Jack Dawson in James Cameron's Titanic, became global superstar, film became highest-grossing ever

lifeEvents.title: Founded the Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation
lifeEvents.description: Established foundation focused on environmental conservation, climate change, and biodiversity

lifeEvents.title: The Beach
lifeEvents.description: First major film after Titanic, attempt to move away from heartthrob image

lifeEvents.title: Gangs of New York collaboration with Scorsese
lifeEvents.description: First collaboration with Martin Scorsese, beginning important creative partnership

lifeEvents.title: Catch Me If You Can
lifeEvents.description: Played con artist Frank Abagnale Jr. in Steven Spielberg film, showed comedic range

lifeEvents.title: The Aviator
lifeEvents.description: Portrayed Howard Hughes in Scorsese film, earned Golden Globe and another Oscar nomination

lifeEvents.title: Blood Diamond
lifeEvents.description: Played South African diamond smuggler, tackled serious subject matter of conflict diamonds

lifeEvents.title: The Departed
lifeEvents.description: Starred in Scorsese's Oscar-winning crime thriller as undercover cop

lifeEvents.title: Starred in 'Inception'
lifeEvents.description: Played Dom Cobb in Christopher Nolan's mind-bending thriller, one of his most acclaimed performances

lifeEvents.title: Django Unchained
lifeEvents.description: Played villain Calvin Candie in Quentin Tarantino's western, showed range in antagonist role

lifeEvents.title: The Wolf of Wall Street
lifeEvents.description: Portrayed Jordan Belfort in Scorsese film, earned another Oscar nomination

lifeEvents.title: The Revenant
lifeEvents.description: Endured harsh filming conditions playing Hugh Glass in survival epic

lifeEvents.title: Won an Academy Award
lifeEvents.description: Finally won Oscar for Best Actor for The Revenant after 5 previous nominations

lifeEvents.title: Delivered environmental speech at Oscars
lifeEvents.description: Used Oscar acceptance speech to highlight climate change, becoming viral moment

lifeEvents.title: Before the Flood documentary
lifeEvents.description: Produced and starred in climate change documentary as UN Messenger of Peace

lifeEvents.title: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood
lifeEvents.description: Starred in Tarantino's 1960s Hollywood film, earned another Oscar nomination

lifeEvents.title: Don't Look Up
lifeEvents.description: Starred in Netflix climate change satire, produced film addressing environmental concerns

lifeEvents.title: Killers of the Flower Moon
lifeEvents.description: Reunited with Scorsese for epic about Osage murders, another Oscar contender performance

lifeEvents.title: Born in Atlanta, Georgia
lifeEvents.description: Born Michael King Jr. to Alberta Williams King and Michael King Sr., later changed to Martin Luther

lifeEvents.title: Attended Morehouse College
lifeEvents.description: Entered at age 15, studied sociology and decided to enter ministry

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from Morehouse
lifeEvents.description: Received Bachelor of Arts in sociology, decided to pursue ministry

lifeEvents.title: Attended Crozer Seminary
lifeEvents.description: Studied at Crozer Theological Seminary in Pennsylvania, class president and valedictorian

lifeEvents.title: Ordained as a Baptist Minister
lifeEvents.description: Ordained as Baptist minister, co-pastored with father at Ebenezer Baptist Church

lifeEvents.title: Attended Boston University
lifeEvents.description: Pursued doctorate in systematic theology, met future wife Coretta Scott

lifeEvents.title: Married Coretta Scott
lifeEvents.description: Married Coretta Scott King in Marion, Alabama

lifeEvents.title: Became pastor in Montgomery
lifeEvents.description: Became pastor of Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Alabama

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Yolanda born
lifeEvents.description: First child Yolanda Denise King born

lifeEvents.title: Rosa Parks arrested
lifeEvents.description: Rosa Parks arrested for refusing to give up bus seat, sparked Montgomery Bus Boycott

lifeEvents.title: Led the Montgomery Bus Boycott
lifeEvents.description: Led 381-day boycott that ended bus segregation, emerged as civil rights leader

lifeEvents.title: House bombed
lifeEvents.description: Family home bombed during boycott, responded with message of nonviolence

lifeEvents.title: Received PhD
lifeEvents.description: Earned doctorate from Boston University in systematic theology

lifeEvents.title: Rose as a Civil Rights Leader
lifeEvents.description: After bus boycott success, became national leader of civil rights movement

lifeEvents.title: Founded SCLC
lifeEvents.description: Co-founded Southern Christian Leadership Conference to coordinate civil rights activities

lifeEvents.title: Son Martin III born
lifeEvents.description: Son Martin Luther King III born

lifeEvents.title: Published Stride Toward Freedom
lifeEvents.description: First book about Montgomery Bus Boycott and philosophy of nonviolence

lifeEvents.title: Stabbed in Harlem
lifeEvents.description: Nearly killed by deranged woman with letter opener while signing books

lifeEvents.title: Trip to India
lifeEvents.description: Visited India to study Gandhi's nonviolent resistance methods

lifeEvents.title: Son Dexter born
lifeEvents.description: Son Dexter Scott King born

lifeEvents.title: Albany Movement
lifeEvents.description: Led desegregation campaign in Albany, Georgia, considered tactical failure but learning experience

lifeEvents.title: Birmingham Campaign
lifeEvents.description: Led campaign against segregation in Birmingham, Alabama, faced violent police response

lifeEvents.title: Arrested in Birmingham
lifeEvents.description: Arrested during Birmingham protests, wrote 'Letter from Birmingham Jail'

lifeEvents.title: Letter from Birmingham Jail
lifeEvents.description: Wrote influential letter defending civil disobedience and nonviolent resistance

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Bernice born
lifeEvents.description: Youngest child Bernice Albertine King born

lifeEvents.title: March on Washington
lifeEvents.description: Led March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom with 250,000 participants

lifeEvents.title: Delivered the 'I Have a Dream' Speech
lifeEvents.description: Delivered iconic 'I Have a Dream' speech at Lincoln Memorial, defining moment of civil rights movement

lifeEvents.title: Named Time Person of the Year
lifeEvents.description: First African American to be named Time magazine's Person of the Year

lifeEvents.title: Nobel Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: At age 35, became youngest person to receive Nobel Peace Prize

lifeEvents.title: Civil Rights Act passed
lifeEvents.description: President Johnson signed Civil Rights Act, largely influenced by King's campaigns

lifeEvents.title: Organized the Selma to Montgomery March
lifeEvents.description: Led voting rights marches from Selma to Montgomery, faced 'Bloody Sunday' violence

lifeEvents.title: Voting Rights Act passed
lifeEvents.description: President Johnson signed Voting Rights Act, direct result of Selma campaigns

lifeEvents.title: Chicago Freedom Movement
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Chicago to address housing discrimination and urban poverty

lifeEvents.title: Opposition to Vietnam War
lifeEvents.description: Delivered 'Beyond Vietnam' speech at Riverside Church, opposed Vietnam War

lifeEvents.title: Poor People's Campaign planned
lifeEvents.description: Planned massive campaign to address economic inequality across racial lines

lifeEvents.title: Memphis sanitation strike support
lifeEvents.description: Traveled to Memphis to support striking sanitation workers

lifeEvents.title: Mountaintop speech
lifeEvents.description: Delivered prophetic 'I've Been to the Mountaintop' speech in Memphis

lifeEvents.title: Assassinated
lifeEvents.description: Shot and killed by James Earl Ray at Lorraine Motel in Memphis, age 39

lifeEvents.title: Funeral and national mourning
lifeEvents.description: Funeral attended by 300,000 people, riots erupted in over 100 cities nationwide

lifeEvents.title: Born in Warsaw, Poland
lifeEvents.description: Born Maria Salomea Skłodowska in Warsaw, then part of Russian Empire, to teachers Władysław and Bronisława Skłodowska

lifeEvents.title: Mother died of tuberculosis
lifeEvents.description: Mother Bronisława died when Maria was 10, family faced financial hardship

lifeEvents.title: Education in Warsaw
lifeEvents.description: Attended gymnasium in Warsaw, excelled in studies despite restrictions on Polish education under Russian rule

lifeEvents.title: Graduated from gymnasium with gold medal
lifeEvents.description: Graduated first in her class with gold medal, but couldn't attend university in Poland as women were barred

lifeEvents.title: Work as Governess
lifeEvents.description: Worked as governess to earn money for sister Bronya's medical studies in Paris, also taught in 'Flying University' (illegal Polish education)

lifeEvents.title: Moved to Paris
lifeEvents.description: Moved to Paris to study, enrolled at Sorbonne under French name 'Marie'

lifeEvents.title: Study at Sorbonne University
lifeEvents.description: Studied physics and mathematics at University of Paris, lived in poverty in sixth-floor apartment

lifeEvents.title: Licentiateships in Physics and Mathematics
lifeEvents.description: Graduated first in license ès sciences (physics) and second in license ès mathématiques

lifeEvents.title: Met Pierre Curie
lifeEvents.description: Introduced to Pierre Curie by Polish physicist Professor Józef Wierusz-Kowalski, needed lab space for steel magnetism research

lifeEvents.title: Marriage to Pierre Curie
lifeEvents.description: Married Pierre Curie in simple civil ceremony, honeymoon was bicycle tour through French countryside

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Irène born
lifeEvents.description: First daughter Irène born, later became Nobel Prize-winning scientist like her mother

lifeEvents.title: Began studying uranium rays
lifeEvents.description: Chose to study uranium rays discovered by Henri Becquerel for doctoral thesis

lifeEvents.title: Discovery of Radium and Polonium
lifeEvents.description: Discovered polonium (July) and radium (December) while studying pitchblende ore, coined term 'radioactivity'

lifeEvents.title: Published groundbreaking radioactivity paper
lifeEvents.description: Published paper coining term 'radioactivity' and establishing it as atomic property

lifeEvents.title: Polonium discovery announced
lifeEvents.description: Announced discovery of polonium, named after her homeland Poland

lifeEvents.title: Radium discovery announced
lifeEvents.description: Announced discovery of radium with Pierre and Gustave Bémont

lifeEvents.title: Daughter Eve born
lifeEvents.description: Second daughter Eve born, later became journalist and biographer

lifeEvents.title: Isolated pure radium
lifeEvents.description: Successfully isolated radium chloride and determined atomic weight as 225.93

lifeEvents.title: First Nobel Prize (Physics)
lifeEvents.description: Shared Nobel Prize in Physics with Pierre and Henri Becquerel for discovery of radioactivity, first woman to win Nobel Prize

lifeEvents.title: Received doctorate degree
lifeEvents.description: Defended doctoral thesis 'Research on Radioactive Substances' at Sorbonne

lifeEvents.title: Pierre's tragic death
lifeEvents.description: Pierre killed in street accident, struck by horse-drawn wagon in Paris, Marie devastated

lifeEvents.title: Professor at Sorbonne
lifeEvents.description: Became first female professor at University of Paris, took over Pierre's teaching position

lifeEvents.title: Second Nobel Prize (Chemistry)
lifeEvents.description: Won Nobel Prize in Chemistry for discovery of radium and polonium, first person to win Nobel Prize twice

lifeEvents.title: Scandal with Paul Langevin
lifeEvents.description: Love affair with married physicist Paul Langevin became public scandal, faced xenophobic attacks

lifeEvents.title: Founded Radium Institute
lifeEvents.description: Founded Radium Institute in Paris (later Curie Institute) for nuclear physics and chemistry research

lifeEvents.title: Director of Red Cross Radiology
lifeEvents.description: Developed mobile X-ray units ('petites Curies') for battlefield hospitals during WWI, personally drove to front lines

lifeEvents.title: First U.S. visit
lifeEvents.description: Triumphant tour of United States, received 1 gram of radium from American women

lifeEvents.title: Published Pierre Curie biography
lifeEvents.description: Published biography of late husband Pierre Curie

lifeEvents.title: Warsaw Radium Institute founding
lifeEvents.description: Participated in laying foundation stone for Warsaw Radium Institute in Poland

lifeEvents.title: International Committee on Intellectual Cooperation
lifeEvents.description: Served on League of Nations committee with Einstein, Bergson, and other prominent intellectuals

lifeEvents.title: Health deterioration
lifeEvents.description: Health declining due to radiation exposure, developed aplastic anemia

lifeEvents.title: Final scientific work
lifeEvents.description: Last months working on artificial radioactivity with daughter Irène and son-in-law Frédéric

lifeEvents.title: Death from radiation exposure
lifeEvents.description: Died at age 66 of aplastic anemia at Sancellemoz sanatorium in French Alps, caused by lifetime radiation exposure

lifeEvents.title: Interred in Panthéon
lifeEvents.description: Remains moved to Panthéon in Paris with Pierre, first woman honored in her own right

lifeEvents.title: Born in Skopje
lifeEvents.description: Born Anjezë Gonxhe Bojaxhiu in Skopje, Ottoman Empire (now North Macedonia), to Albanian parents

lifeEvents.title: Father died
lifeEvents.description: Father Nikollë Bojaxhiu died when she was 8, mother raised three children alone

lifeEvents.title: Felt calling to religious life
lifeEvents.description: At age 18, felt called to missionary work, decided to become nun

lifeEvents.title: Joined Sisters of Loreto
lifeEvents.description: Left home to join Irish Sisters of Loreto in Dublin, never saw mother or sister again

lifeEvents.title: Arrived in India
lifeEvents.description: Arrived in Calcutta, India, began teaching at St. Mary's School for girls

lifeEvents.title: Took religious vows
lifeEvents.description: Took first religious vows as Sister Teresa, named after Saint Thérèse of Lisieux

lifeEvents.title: Became Mother Teresa
lifeEvents.description: Took final vows and became 'Mother Teresa', taught at St. Mary's High School

lifeEvents.title: 'Call within a call'
lifeEvents.description: Experienced vision on train to Darjeeling calling her to work with 'poorest of the poor'

lifeEvents.title: Left convent
lifeEvents.description: Received permission to leave Loreto convent and work in Calcutta slums

lifeEvents.title: Started humanitarian work in Calcutta
lifeEvents.description: Began working in Motijhil slum, teaching children and caring for dying

lifeEvents.title: Became Indian citizen
lifeEvents.description: Obtained Indian citizenship to work more effectively with the poor

lifeEvents.title: Founded the Missionaries of Charity
lifeEvents.description: Established new religious congregation dedicated to serving 'poorest of the poor'

lifeEvents.title: Opened Home for the Dying
lifeEvents.description: Opened Nirmal Hriday (Pure Heart) hospice in former Hindu temple for dying destitute

lifeEvents.title: First orphanage opened
lifeEvents.description: Opened Nirmala Shishu Bhavan children's home for orphans and abandoned children

lifeEvents.title: Work with lepers began
lifeEvents.description: Started mobile leprosy clinic, later opened treatment center for lepers

lifeEvents.title: International recognition began
lifeEvents.description: Padma Shri award from Indian government, first of many international honors

lifeEvents.title: Missions expanded internationally
lifeEvents.description: Opened first house outside India in Venezuela, missions spread worldwide

lifeEvents.title: Opened house in Rome
lifeEvents.description: Established mission in Rome, brought work closer to Vatican

lifeEvents.title: First BBC documentary
lifeEvents.description: Malcolm Muggeridge's documentary 'Something Beautiful for God' brought international fame

lifeEvents.title: Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize
lifeEvents.description: Received Nobel Peace Prize 'for work undertaken in the struggle to overcome poverty and distress'

lifeEvents.title: Refused traditional Nobel banquet
lifeEvents.description: Asked Nobel Committee to cancel banquet and give money to poor instead

lifeEvents.title: Expanded work to developed countries
lifeEvents.description: Opened houses in Harlem, London, and other Western cities for AIDS patients and homeless

lifeEvents.title: Heart problems began
lifeEvents.description: First heart attack while visiting Pope John Paul II in Rome

lifeEvents.title: Peace mission to Beirut
lifeEvents.description: Traveled to war-torn Beirut to rescue 37 children from front line hospital

lifeEvents.title: Met Princess Diana
lifeEvents.description: Met Princess Diana, both worked for similar humanitarian causes

lifeEvents.title: Resigned as Superior General
lifeEvents.description: Resigned leadership of Missionaries of Charity due to failing health

lifeEvents.title: Last public appearance
lifeEvents.description: Met Pope John Paul II for final time, continued working despite heart problems

lifeEvents.title: Death
lifeEvents.description: Died of heart failure in Calcutta at age 87, millions mourned worldwide

lifeEvents.title: State funeral
lifeEvents.description: Given state funeral by Indian government, attended by world leaders

lifeEvents.title: Beatification
lifeEvents.description: Beatified by Pope John Paul II, became Blessed Teresa of Calcutta

lifeEvents.title: Canonization
lifeEvents.description: Canonized as Saint Teresa of Calcutta by Pope Francis

lifeEvents.title: Born in Porbandar, India
lifeEvents.description: Born Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in Porbandar, Gujarat, to Karamchand Gandhi (diwan) and Putlibai Gandhi

lifeEvents.title: Child marriage to Kasturbai
lifeEvents.description: Married Kasturbai Makhanji at age 13 in arranged marriage, had four sons together

lifeEvents.title: Studied Law in London
lifeEvents.description: Studied law at Inner Temple London, became barrister, struggled with Western lifestyle

lifeEvents.title: Failed legal practice in India
lifeEvents.description: Returned to India but unsuccessful as lawyer in Bombay and Rajkot

lifeEvents.title: Moved to South Africa
lifeEvents.description: Accepted one-year contract with Indian law firm in Pretoria, South Africa

lifeEvents.title: Train incident and racial awakening
lifeEvents.description: Thrown off train at Pietermaritzburg despite having first-class ticket, pivotal moment in consciousness

lifeEvents.title: Founded Natal Indian Congress
lifeEvents.description: Established organization to fight discrimination against Indians in South Africa

lifeEvents.title: Developed satyagraha philosophy
lifeEvents.description: Launched first satyagraha (truth-force) campaign against discriminatory laws

lifeEvents.title: Phoenix Settlement founded
lifeEvents.description: Established intentional community based on simple living and self-sufficiency

lifeEvents.title: Tolstoy Farm established
lifeEvents.description: Founded second commune near Johannesburg, named after Leo Tolstoy

lifeEvents.title: Returned to India permanently
lifeEvents.description: Returned to India as celebrated leader, called 'Mahatma' (great soul) by Rabindranath Tagore

lifeEvents.title: Led the Indian Independence Movement
lifeEvents.description: Became leader of Indian National Congress and independence movement using non-violent resistance

lifeEvents.title: Champaran Satyagraha
lifeEvents.description: First major satyagraha in India, helped indigo farmers against British exploitation

lifeEvents.title: Kheda Satyagraha
lifeEvents.description: Led farmers' revolt against excessive taxation during famine

lifeEvents.title: Rowlatt Act protests
lifeEvents.description: Called for nation-wide hartal (strike) against repressive Rowlatt Act

lifeEvents.title: Jallianwala Bagh response
lifeEvents.description: After Jallianwala Bagh massacre, escalated non-cooperation movement

lifeEvents.title: Non-Cooperation Movement
lifeEvents.description: Led massive non-violent resistance campaign against British rule

lifeEvents.title: Adopted spinning wheel (charkha)
lifeEvents.description: Made spinning wheel symbol of self-reliance and resistance to British cloth

lifeEvents.title: Suspended movement after Chauri Chaura
lifeEvents.description: Suspended non-cooperation after violent incident at Chauri Chaura

lifeEvents.title: Arrested and imprisoned
lifeEvents.description: Sentenced to six years imprisonment for sedition, served two years

lifeEvents.title: Published autobiography
lifeEvents.description: Serialized 'The Story of My Experiments with Truth' in his journal

lifeEvents.title: Simon Commission boycott
lifeEvents.description: Led boycott of all-British commission on constitutional reform

lifeEvents.title: Purna Swaraj declaration
lifeEvents.description: Congress declared complete independence as goal, not just dominion status

lifeEvents.title: Led the Salt March
lifeEvents.description: Led 240-mile march to Dandi to make salt, breaking British salt monopoly law

lifeEvents.title: Salt Satyagraha launched
lifeEvents.description: Made salt at Dandi beach, triggered nationwide civil disobedience

lifeEvents.title: Gandhi-Irwin Pact
lifeEvents.description: Signed agreement with Viceroy Lord Irwin, suspended civil disobedience

lifeEvents.title: Round Table Conference London
lifeEvents.description: Represented Congress at Second Round Table Conference in London

lifeEvents.title: Quit India Movement
lifeEvents.description: Launched 'Do or Die' movement demanding immediate British withdrawal

lifeEvents.title: Imprisoned during WWII
lifeEvents.description: Arrested with other leaders, spent war years in Aga Khan Palace prison

lifeEvents.title: Wife Kasturbai died
lifeEvents.description: Kasturbai died in prison after 62 years of marriage

lifeEvents.title: Partition of India accepted
lifeEvents.description: Reluctantly accepted partition of India and Pakistan to avoid civil war

lifeEvents.title: Independence achieved
lifeEvents.description: India gained independence, but Gandhi mourned partition violence

lifeEvents.title: Fasted for peace
lifeEvents.description: Began series of fasts to stop Hindu-Muslim violence after partition

lifeEvents.title: Final fast for peace
lifeEvents.description: Last fast to ensure fair treatment of Muslims and end communal violence

lifeEvents.title: Assassinated
lifeEvents.description: Shot and killed by Hindu nationalist Nathuram Godse at prayer meeting in New Delhi

lifeEvents.title: Final words 'Hey Ram'
lifeEvents.description: Last words were 'Hey Ram' (Oh God), died advocating non-violence to the end

lifeEvents.title: Born in Blenheim Palace, England
lifeEvents.description: Born to Lord Randolph Churchill and Jennie Jerome (American heiress) at Blenheim Palace, Oxfordshire

lifeEvents.title: Attended Harrow School
lifeEvents.description: Poor student but excelled in English and history, developed love of military matters

lifeEvents.title: Royal Military College Sandhurst
lifeEvents.description: Graduated 20th out of 130, commissioned as second lieutenant in 4th Queen's Own Hussars

lifeEvents.title: Served in the British Army
lifeEvents.description: Served in India and Sudan, combined military service with journalism

lifeEvents.title: War correspondent in Cuba
lifeEvents.description: Covered Cuban War of Independence, first taste of combat and journalism

lifeEvents.title: Northwest Frontier campaign
lifeEvents.description: Participated in Malakand Frontier Force campaign on India's Northwest Frontier

lifeEvents.title: Published first book
lifeEvents.description: 'The Story of the Malakand Field Force' established him as writer

lifeEvents.title: Battle of Omdurman
lifeEvents.description: Participated in last major British cavalry charge in Sudan campaign

lifeEvents.title: Boer War correspondent and prisoner
lifeEvents.description: Captured by Boers, escaped dramatically from Pretoria prison, became famous

lifeEvents.title: Elected to Parliament
lifeEvents.description: Elected Conservative MP for Oldham at age 25

lifeEvents.title: Crossed floor to Liberal Party
lifeEvents.description: Left Conservative Party over free trade, joined Liberals

lifeEvents.title: Married Clementine Hozier
lifeEvents.description: Married Clementine Hozier at St. Margaret's Westminster, lifelong partnership

lifeEvents.title: President of Board of Trade
lifeEvents.description: First major government position, introduced labor exchanges and unemployment insurance

lifeEvents.title: Home Secretary
lifeEvents.description: Controversial tenure including Tonypandy riots and Sidney Street siege

lifeEvents.title: First Lord of the Admiralty
lifeEvents.description: Modernized Royal Navy for WWI, prepared fleet for war

lifeEvents.title: Dardanelles/Gallipoli disaster
lifeEvents.description: Championed failed Gallipoli campaign, forced to resign from Admiralty

lifeEvents.title: Served on Western Front
lifeEvents.description: Commanded 6th Battalion Royal Scots Fusiliers in France

lifeEvents.title: Minister of Munitions
lifeEvents.description: Oversaw war production, helped win WWI with increased munitions output

lifeEvents.title: Secretary of State for War and Air
lifeEvents.description: Managed demobilization, opposed Bolshevism, advocated intervention in Russia

lifeEvents.title: Colonial Secretary
lifeEvents.description: Oversaw Middle East mandates, created modern Iraq and Jordan

lifeEvents.title: Lost seat, out of Parliament
lifeEvents.description: 'Without office, without seat, without party' - his own description

lifeEvents.title: Rejoined Conservative Party
lifeEvents.description: Returned to Conservative Party, elected MP for Epping

lifeEvents.title: Chancellor of the Exchequer
lifeEvents.description: Returned Britain to gold standard (later seen as mistake), handled General Strike

lifeEvents.title: Wilderness Years began
lifeEvents.description: Out of government for 10 years, warned against Nazi Germany and appeasement

lifeEvents.title: Began writing 'The World Crisis'
lifeEvents.description: Six-volume history of WWI, established reputation as historian

lifeEvents.title: Wall Street Crash visit
lifeEvents.description: Witnessed Black Thursday Wall Street Crash firsthand while in New York

lifeEvents.title: Anti-Nazi speeches began
lifeEvents.description: Consistently warned about Hitler's threat while government pursued appeasement

lifeEvents.title: Published 'Marlborough' biography
lifeEvents.description: Four-volume biography of ancestor Duke of Marlborough

lifeEvents.title: Edward VIII abdication crisis
lifeEvents.description: Supported King Edward VIII, damaged reputation when king abdicated

lifeEvents.title: Munich Agreement opposition
lifeEvents.description: Opposed Chamberlain's appeasement policy at Munich

lifeEvents.title: War declared, returned to Admiralty
lifeEvents.description: Appointed First Lord of Admiralty again, 'Winston is back' signaled to fleet

lifeEvents.title: Norway campaign
lifeEvents.description: Led failed Norwegian campaign, but Chamberlain took blame

lifeEvents.title: Became Prime Minister
lifeEvents.description: Appointed PM as Germany invaded France, formed coalition government

lifeEvents.title: First Term as Prime Minister
lifeEvents.description: Led Britain through WWII, formed Grand Alliance with US and USSR

lifeEvents.title: 'Blood, toil, tears and sweat' speech
lifeEvents.description: First speech as PM to House of Commons, defined his mission

lifeEvents.title: Gave 'We shall fight on the beaches' speech
lifeEvents.description: Iconic speech after Dunkirk evacuation, inspired British resistance

lifeEvents.title: 'Their finest hour' speech
lifeEvents.description: Rallied Britain before Battle of Britain, predicted victory

lifeEvents.title: Battle of Britain
lifeEvents.description: Led Britain through aerial battle, praised RAF pilots

lifeEvents.title: The Blitz
lifeEvents.description: Maintained morale during German bombing campaign of British cities

lifeEvents.title: Atlantic Charter with Roosevelt
lifeEvents.description: Met FDR off Newfoundland, established war aims and post-war vision

lifeEvents.title: Pearl Harbor response
lifeEvents.description: Rejoiced at US entry into war: 'We have won after all!'

lifeEvents.title: Tehran Conference
lifeEvents.description: First Big Three meeting with Roosevelt and Stalin

lifeEvents.title: D-Day planning and execution
lifeEvents.description: Helped plan and oversee successful Normandy invasion

lifeEvents.title: Yalta Conference
lifeEvents.description: Final Big Three meeting, agreed on post-war Europe division

lifeEvents.title: VE Day celebration
lifeEvents.description: Led Britain's celebration of victory in Europe

lifeEvents.title: Lost 1945 election
lifeEvents.description: Labour Party won landslide, Churchill voted out despite war victory

lifeEvents.title: Delivered 'Iron Curtain' speech
lifeEvents.description: Warned of Soviet threat at Fulton, Missouri, coined 'Iron Curtain' phrase

lifeEvents.title: Began 'The Second World War'
lifeEvents.description: Six-volume history of WWII, won Nobel Prize for Literature

lifeEvents.title: Second Term as Prime Minister
lifeEvents.description: Returned as PM at age 76, focused on Cold War and nuclear weapons

lifeEvents.title: Awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature
lifeEvents.description: Won Nobel Prize 'for his mastery of historical and biographical description'

lifeEvents.title: Knighted by Queen Elizabeth II
lifeEvents.description: Made Knight of the Garter by new Queen

lifeEvents.title: Stroke and health decline
lifeEvents.description: Suffered major stroke, kept secret from public

lifeEvents.title: Retired as Prime Minister
lifeEvents.description: Resigned as PM at age 80, remained MP

lifeEvents.title: Published 'A History of the English-Speaking Peoples'
lifeEvents.description: Four-volume history from Caesar to Victorian era

lifeEvents.title: Made Honorary Citizen of United States
lifeEvents.description: First person to receive honorary U.S. citizenship

lifeEvents.title: Retired from Parliament
lifeEvents.description: Did not stand for re-election after 64 years in politics

lifeEvents.title: Death and state funeral
lifeEvents.description: Died at age 90, given state funeral at St. Paul's Cathedral, largest in British history

lifeEvents.title: Born in Sandringham, England
lifeEvents.description: Born Diana Frances Spencer at Park House on Sandringham estate, youngest daughter of Earl Spencer

lifeEvents.title: Parents divorced
lifeEvents.description: Parents John Spencer and Frances Roche divorced when Diana was 7, custody battle

lifeEvents.title: Father became Earl Spencer
lifeEvents.description: Family inherited title and Althorp estate when grandfather died

lifeEvents.title: Left school at 16
lifeEvents.description: Poor academic performance, left West Heath School without qualifications

lifeEvents.title: Worked as kindergarten assistant
